etymologies: Old English sunne, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zon and German Sonne, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek hēlios and Latin sol

definitions: the star around which the earth orbits

examples.text: the sun shone from a cloudless sky
he watched the sun go down over the sea

notes.text: The sun is the central body of the solar system. It provides the light and energy that sustains life on earth, and its position relative to the earth's axis determines the terrestrial seasons. The sun is a star of a type known as a G2 dwarf, a sphere of hydrogen and helium 870,000 miles (1.4 million km) in diameter that obtains its energy from nuclear fusion reactions in its interior, where the temperature is about 15 million°C. The surface is a little under 6,000°C

definitions: any star in the universe that is similar to the sun, with or without planets.
shortDefinitions: any star in universe similar to sun, with or without planets

definitions: the light or warmth received from the earth's sun

examples.text: we sat outside in the sun

shortDefinitions: light or warmth received from sun

definitions: a person or thing regarded as a source of glory, inspiration, or understanding

examples.text: the rhetoric faded before the sun of reality

definitions: used with reference to someone's success or prosperity

examples.text: the sun of the Plantagenets went down in clouds

shortDefinitions: used of someone's success or prosperity

examples.text: after going so many suns without food, I was sleeping

phrases.text: on which the sun never sets

definitions: sit or lie in the sun

examples.text: Buzz could see Clare sunning herself on the terrace below

definitions: expose (something) to the sun, especially to warm or dry it

examples.text: the birds are sunning their wings

phrases.text: on which the sun never sets
